Award.AwardTitle: Hybrid molecular modeling and experimental study of structure and reaction kinetics at interface between electrode and polymer electrolyte phases

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0933393
Zhou

Project Summary

Although great efforts have been focused on developments of more effective and/or low cost electrocatalysts and polymer electrolytes for polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFC) in the last 30 years, the essential technical requirements for performance, durability, and cost have not been satisfied. One of the major barriers for PEFC technology is the very slow reaction kinetics and high activation polarization for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode. The fact that the ORR exchange current density at the Pt/Nafion interface is about 3 orders of magnitude lower than that at the Pt/sulfuric acid interface suggests that the coupling between an electrocatalyst and an electrolyte is critical. This provides a perfect case for theoreticians to study and elucidate the mystery with respect to interfaces. Therefore, a unified approach is proposed to focus on the electrocatalyst/electrolyte couple rather than the electrocatalyst and polymer electrolyte separately.

Intellectual Merits: The objectives of this research are to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms that cause the orders of magnitude differences in reaction kinetics between different electrocatalyst/electrolyte couples, and to establish a cost effective methodology for designing and computer-testing more effective and/or low cost electrocatalyst/electrolyte couples for PEFCs. To reach the objectives, a high throughput hybrid atomistic simulation methodology will be developed and it will be assisted by in situ X-ray absorption analysis to define the atomic structure or electric double layer (EDL) structures. This methodology will be used to evaluate the electrochemical charge transfer and polarization in ORR at the electrocatalysts/polymer electrolyte interface in contrast to the electrocatalysts/liquid electrolyte (e.g.H2SO4) interface. The unified approach in electrocatalyst and polymer electrolyte research is novel and has the potential to improve our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of the EDL between an electrocatyst and a polymer electrolyte and the charge transfer characteristics. Furthermore, the proposed research will also promote the fundamental understanding of all other electrochemical systems that involve solid-state electrolytes, such as high performance lithium-ion batteries, photoelectrochemical cells, and supercapacitors.

Broader impact: The proposed work will (1) enhance ongoing PhD research programs on PEFCs and solid-state supercapacitors by providing new tools of molecular modeling techniques to the study of energy conversion processes; (2) attract, encourage, and support outstanding undergraduate students to pursue a PhD study; (3) integrate the information on molecular simulation into curricula of the courses taught by the PI and Co-PI; (4) integrate the information into regular community education tasks; and (5) promote education of female and minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Great efforts have been focused on developments of more effective electrocatalysts and polymer electrolytes for polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFC) in 30 years. One of the major barriers for PEFC technology is the very slow reaction kinetics and high activation polarization for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode.  The fact that the true ORR exchange current density at the Pt/Nafion interface is much lower than that at the Pt/sulfuric acid interface suggests that there is room for a quantum jump improvement for PEFC. In the commonly accepted description, the potential drop at the interface is defined as the electrochemical potential (ECP) which is the key concept in electrochemistry. The potential varies as a function of position in the so-called electric double layer (EDL).  Accordingly, the ECP and potential distribution in the EDL dictate the electrochemical reaction kinetics.  By using the atomistic simulation tools, our finding is that a potential drop does exist across the interface for ions but does not exist for electrons. This is a logically in line with the Schrödinger equation under the adiabatic or Born-Oppenheimer (BO) approximation. If this is proven, the exchange current density is indirectly dependent on the ECP through the response of ions to the ECP which is valid only for ions. The second significant finding is that electron can actually tunnel through a thick Nafion film. This allows STM imaging the interface between Nafion and an electronic conductor substrate. A theoretical analysis provides an explanation of this anomalous phenomenon which may be utilized for improving the performance of various types of electrochemical power sources in orders of magnitude. Other findings are as follows.

1)         The electrolyte molecules form a few highly ordered layers on top of Pt crystal.

2)         The molecules in the highly ordered layers do certain collective motions.

3)         Reduction of oxygen at the cathode is facilitated by water and oxidation of hydrogen is hindered by water, correlating with the picture of the EDL structure.

4)         Increasing proton in the electrolyte increases the potential drop at interface. Introducing water and adsorption of oxygen and hydrogen decrease the potential drop.

Based on the present findings, it is suggested that the concepts and theories that have been employed for a long period in electrochemistry requires reconsiderations and revisions. This will give rise to new visions and practice in the science and engineering of electrochemical power sources.

 

The project supported 5 PhD students. These PhD students were benefited by the availability of the atomistic simulation tools and expertise. One thesis was on the topic of the atomistic simulation of the Nafion-Pt interface. In other theses atomistic simulation tools were used to give explanations of materials behaviors. The research project attracted and encouraged at least 2 undergraduate students to pursue PhD studentships. The PI integrated the information on molecular simulation into curricula of the courses taught by the PI and co-PI. The PI has formulated and established a new graduate course “Atomistic simulation of nanomaterials” using the knowledge, software and hardware obtained from this project. 3 female students and 6 minority students were trained in this project.
